verbs.description: maunder (third-person singular simple present maunders, present participle maundering, simple past and past participle maundered)

entries.meaning: To speak in a disorganized or desultory manner; to babble or prattle.
examples: "Not so fast, Lady Cecilia; not yet;" and now Louisa went on with a medical maundering. "As to low spirits, my dear Cecilia, I must say I agree with Sir Sib Pennyfeather, who tells me it is not mere common low spirits  […] "
[Deacon Mushrat to Pogo:] The Machiavellian barratry of a pettifogging public has maundered into do-nothingism.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, obsolete) To beg; to whine like a beggar.
